contentrichtext.text: {{lowercase}}{{Infobox software | name=gconf-editor | logo=[[Image:Gconf-editor logo.png]] | screenshot=[[Image:Gconf-editor on Ubuntu.png|250px]] | caption=gconf-editor on [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] | latest_release_version=3.0.1<ref>http://ftp.gnome.org/pub/gnome/sources/gconf-editor/3.0/</ref> | latest_release_date= | genre=Configuration editor | operating_system=[[BSD]], [[Linux]], [[UNIX]] | license=[[GNU General Public License|GPL]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gentoo-portage.com/gnome-extra/gconf-editor |title=Gentoo-Portage gconf-editor page |}}</ref> | website=[http://www.gnome.org/ www.gnome.org] }} '''Gconf-editor''' is an application for the [[GNOME]] computer desktop environment. It can be considered the graphical equivalent of [[gconftool]] and is used to maintain the GNOME registry. Gconf-editor gives users the ability to access settings stored in the [[XML]]-based [[GConf]] configuration [[database]] or registry. It is used primarily by developers to [[debug]] [[application software|applications]], or by [[power user]]s to edit hidden and complex settings. It [[abstraction|abstracts]] the values from the GConf database and presents them in an interface similar to [[Microsoft Windows]]' [[Windows registry|registry]] editor. Traditional CLI (Command Line Interface) power users of GNOME have criticized it as an excuse to oversimplify the user interface and design for the [[lowest common denominator]]. Preferences such as turning off desktop icons or changing window button order are not available through a friendly [[graphical user interface]] (GUI), like other settings, but can only be changed using gconf-editor. GNOME core developers claim{{Who|date=October 2007}} that the majority of users find lots of options and choices confusing and difficult to learn, and that so-called power users have little difficulty finding options using an application such as Gconf-editor.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} Due to the controversy, other gconf tools have appeared, such as Gconfpref by [[MandrakeSoft]]. There are also [[patch (computing)|patches]] for popular applications, which add the ability to change the hidden options from within the application itself, avoiding the need for gconf-editor. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{portal|Free Software}} * [http://www.gnome.org/projects/gconf/ GConf configuration system] [[Category:GNOME]] {{GNOME-stub}}
